Ananya: I am curious to know more about where such memory comes up. ## Dialogue: Stress–Strain in Viscoelastic Fluids
Acharya Anvaya:Have you heard of the Hooke’s law in solids? ** Ananya** : Yes! It says:
[ (t) = E , (t). ]
The stress responds instantly to strain.
Acharya Anyaya: But how does this change for flowing materials?
Ananya: from what I know, for purely viscous fluids, Newton’s law governs:
[ (t) = , (t). ]
Acharya Anvaya: Here stress depends only on the rate of strain at the present moment.
Ananya: So both Hooke’s law and Newton’s law speak only of the present. They have no memory of what came before?
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly. But the world of polymers is different. These are viscoelastic materials. Their stress at time \(t\) remembers the entire history of strain. It is written as:
[ (t) = _0^t G(t-),(),d, ] where (G) is the relaxation kernel — the weight of memory.
Ananya: So the kernel is like the echoing chamber of the temple — weighing the voices of the past according to distance in time?
Acharya Anvaya: Precisely. If the kernel is exponential, we hear short-lived echoes: the classical Maxwell-type models. But experiments with polymers show something subtler: a power-law decay of memory,
[ G(t-) (t-)^{-}, <<1. ]
Ananya: A power law! Then stress never completely forgets — the ancient echoes fade slowly, but they never vanish.
Acharya Anvaya: Well said. Substituting this kernel transforms the constitutive relation into:
[ (t) = _, D_t^(t), ] where (D_t^) is a fractional derivative of the strain.
Ananya: Then when (), the memory is eternal — purely elastic. When (), memory vanishes quickly — purely viscous. And for (0<<1), we have viscoelasticity, with fading memory that bridges the two.
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly! Thus, the language of fractional calculus is the scripture that describes memory in matter — echoing from the temple walls into the world of flowing polymers.
